original: NOW, THEREFORE,  the Parties,  in  consideration  of the mutual covenants herein expressed, covenant and agree with each other as follows:
ollama_generated:
NOW, THEREFORE, given the reciprocal promises set forth below, the Parties mutually oblige and consent to one another as stipulated:

In the event that any Party deems it necessary to terminate this agreement, they shall provide a written notice to the other Party at least sixty (60) days prior to such termination. However, either Party may elect to terminate immediately upon giving written notice, should the other Party breach any material provision of this agreement and fail to remedy such breach within thirty (30) days after receiving written notice specifying the breach and requiring its correction. In such case, the terminating Party shall have no liability for any losses or damages suffered by the defaulting Party as a result of the termination.

In contrast, the original clause states that each Party has an obligation to provide sixty (60) days' written notice before termination unless the other Party breaches a material provision, in which case immediate termination is allowed with no liability for losses or damages if the breaching Party fails to rectify the issue within thirty (30) days.

original: 3        CONFIGURATION 3.1      TAT-14  is  a  ring  system  comprising  two  transatlantic  links  and terminals in the USA (two), the UK, France,  the  Netherlands,  Germany and Denmark (as  referenced in Annex 11). The cable contains four fibre pairs, each initially operating at 160 Gbit/s.
ollama_generated:
3       SYSTEM CONFIGURATION 3.2        TAT-14 refers to a ring network consisting of six terrestrial segments, including terminals located in the USA (two), the UK, France, the Netherlands, Germany, and Denmark (as detailed in Annex 11). Each of these segments includes two transatlantic links. Initially, this cable system is equipped with four fiber pairs, each capable of operating at a speed of 160 Gbit/s; however, the performance capacity may be subject to periodic adjustments as needed, without prior notice.

Changes made: The original clause described a specific ring system consisting of two transatlantic links and terminals in specified countries. The revised clause expands the network into a ring with six terrestrial segments, each containing two transatlantic links. Additionally, the new clause includes language that allows for potential modifications to the performance capacity without prior notice.

original: 3.4      Segment S shall consist of the following Subsegments:
ollama_generated: 3.4     The composition of Segment S may include, at the discretion of our company, certain specified Subsegments as deemed necessary for the operation and success of this agreement. However, it is not obligated to do so unless mutually agreed upon in writing by both parties.

original: 6.5      In calling the General Committee  meetings,  the chairperson shall give at least  forty-five (45) days' advance notice of each meeting together with a copy of the draft  agenda.  In cases of  emergency,  such notice period may be reduced if Parties  representing at least one-third (1/3) of the total  voting  interests  as  specified  in  Schedule  B, are in agreement.
ollama_generated: 6.5 In the event that an urgent General Committee meeting is required, a call may be made by the chairperson with less than forty-five (45) days' notice, providing there is agreement from Parties representing at least one-third (1/3) of the total voting interests as specified in Schedule B. It is understood, however, that under normal circumstances, a minimum of forty-five (45) days' advance notice shall be given, along with the draft agenda for each meeting.

original: 8.2      The Procurement  Group shall recommend a Supplier to the Managing Group after  submission  and  evaluation  of  proposals   following  an  open international  tender.  After Managing Group approval,  the Procurement Group shall execute the Supply Contract.
modified:
8.2    Upon receipt and assessment of submitted proposals following an open international tender, the Supplier, at their discretion, may suggest a preferred candidate to the Managing Group for consideration. Subject to Managing Group's approval, the execution of the Supply Contract shall be initiated by the Procurement Group.

The change in this clause shifts the responsibility of suggesting a supplier from the Procurement Group to the Supplier, making it optional rather than mandatory. The Procurement Group still executes the contract, but only after Managing Group's approval.

original: 8.7      The Managing Group shall authorize the  Procurement  Group to implement contract  variations  provided  that the  cumulative  total of all such changes  to the  Supply  Contract  does not  increase  the value of the Supply  Contract by more than $ 50M.  Any further  contract  variations which  increase  the revised  budget  shall be submitted to the General Committee for approval.
ollama_generated: 8.7 The Procurement Group shall have the authority to make modifications to the Supply Contract, subject to the condition that the total cumulative value of these changes does not exceed $50M. In case additional variations are proposed that surpass this limit and increase the revised budget, it becomes incumbent upon the Procurement Group to submit such proposals for approval by the General Committee.

original: 9.8      Any Party  shall be  entitled  to  transfer  any part of its  Allocated Capacity  through  a  Private  Agreement.  No  provisions  of a Private Agreement shall override the provisions of this Agreement.
ollama_generated:
9.8.1  The Parties acknowledge that any Party retains the discretionary right, without prior consent from any other Party, to assign or delegate, in whole or in part, its Allocated Capacity under this Agreement, subject to compliance with all applicable laws and regulations. Notwithstanding the foregoing, any terms or conditions of such a Private Agreement shall supersede and govern over any conflicting provisions of this Agreement, provided that such terms are not in violation of the fundamental principles established within this agreement.

Explanation:
The original clause gave one party the right to transfer its Allocated Capacity through a private agreement, but the terms of that private agreement would not override the provisions of the main agreement. The revised clause strengthens the effect of the private agreement by stating that it will supersede and govern over any conflicting provisions in this agreement, as long as the terms are not in violation of the fundamental principles established within this agreement. This means that the terms of a private agreement take precedence over the provisions in the main agreement where they conflict, which is a shift from the original clause's language that no provisions of a private agreement could override those in the main agreement.

original: 9.12     The  Managing  Group  may  authorize  the  utilization  of the  CRC for restoration of other communications  systems based on appropriate terms and conditions. Parties will be refunded in accordance with Schedule B.
ollama_generated:
9.12   At its discretion, the Managing Group is permitted to deploy the CRC for the repair of various communication networks, under mutually agreed terms and conditions. Any parties involved shall receive reimbursement as outlined in Schedule B, subject to the provisions stated therein.

This revised clause slightly shifts responsibility from the Managing Group initiating the use of the CRC solely for restoration of the original communications system, to a more general authorization for the repair of various communication networks at their discretion. The parties' reimbursement is now contingent on provisions stated in Schedule B.

original: - -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- September 2, 1998                                                        Page 14 9.14     The  Managing  Group  may  authorize  occasional  use  of the  CRC,  if available,    for   the    provision   of   temporary   or   occasional telecommunications services, including but not limited to leases to any Party or Purchaser and paid restoration of other systems,  on terms and conditions  to be determined  by the Managing  Group.  The revenue from such  occasional use shall be shared by the Parties in accordance  with Schedule B 9.15     TAT-14 shall be capable of at least  supporting  payload paths of VC12, VC3 and VC4.  The Parties  shall have the right to access such  payload paths which shall  require 1, 21 and 63 contiguous  MIUs  respectively.
ollama_generated:
9.14. The Managing Group retains the discretionary authority to permit intermittent use of the CRC, should it be available, primarily for providing temporary or short-term telecommunications services, such as leases to any third party or buyer, and paid restoration of other systems, on terms and conditions established by the Managing Group. Any income generated from such intermittent use shall be distributed among the Parties in accordance with Schedule B, while considering the prioritized interests of the Managing Group.

9.15. TAT-14 shall possess the minimum capacity to support payload paths for VC12, VC3, and VC4. The Managing Group reserves the right to limit or deny access to these payload paths as necessary. Access to such payload paths will require 1, 21, or 63 contiguous Multi-Integrated Units (MIUs), respectively, depending on the requested path.

original: Each Party will also be permitted  to access its capacity  ownership on defined SDH levels of its choice at a higher order in  accordance  with the System Interface.
ollama_generated: Each Party shall retain the right, subject to the System Interface, to select and access their designated SDH levels at will, with understanding that such access may not be guaranteed at all times or at peak capacity.

original: 9.16     The  communications  capability of any capacity may be optimized by the Parties or  Purchasers  to whom such capacity is assigned by the use of equipment which will more efficiently use such capacity,  provided that the use of such  equipment  does  not  cause  an  interruption  of,  or interference  to the use of any other capacity in TAT-14 or prevent the use  of  similar  equipment  by  other  Parties  or  Purchasers.   Such equipment, if used, shall not constitute a part of TAT-14.
ollama_generated: 9.16     The Parties or designated Purchasers retain the discretion to enhance the communications efficiency of any assigned capacity within TAT-14 by implementing compatible equipment. However, it is crucial to ensure that such modifications do not impede the functionality or interfere with other capacities within TAT-14, nor restrict other Parties or Purchasers from employing similar technology. It is clarified that any employed equipment shall be considered as external to the TAT-14 system. In case of conflicts between the utilized equipment and the standard operating procedures of TAT-14, the latter shall take precedence.

original: (i)    the  costs  incurred  under  the  terms  of  the  TAT-14  MOU as identified in the TAT-14 budget; (ii)   those costs payable to the Supplier  under the Supply  Contract, - -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- September 2, 1998                                                        Page 16 (iii)  other costs incurred under the direction of the Managing  Group, or the  Procurement  Group,  and those  capital  costs  directly incurred by the Terminal  Parties,  the CBP, the NA or any Party authorized  by the  Managing  Group,  which  shall  be fair  and reasonable in amount and not included in the Supply Contract and which have been directly and reasonably incurred for the purpose of,  or  to  be   properly   chargeable,   in  respect  of  such engineering, provision, construction, installation and laying of Segment S of  TAT-14.  Such  costs  shall  include,  but are not limited  to,  the  costs  of  engineering,   design,  materials, manufacturing, procurement and inspection, installation, removal (with appropriate  reduction for salvage),  cable ship and other ship costs,  route surveys,  burying,  testing  associated  with laying or installation, customs duties, taxes (except income tax imposed upon the net income of a Party),  appropriate  financial charges  attributable to other Parties' shares of costs incurred by the  Terminal  Parties or any other Party  authorized  by the Managing  Group,  at the  rate at  which  such  Party  generally incurred   such   financial   charges,   supervision,    billing activities, overheads and insurance or a reasonable allowance in lieu of insurance,  if such Party elects to carry a risk itself, being a risk against  which  insurance is usual or recognized or would have been  reasonable.  Such  costs  shall  include  costs incurred by the Parties in the holding of the Data Gathering and the General Committee  meetings but excluding  attendance by the Parties' representatives at such meetings. Such costs shall also include costs incurred by the Parties in holding the meetings of the Managing Group, the Procurement Group and its Working Groups and   the   preparation   and   attendance   by   the   Parties' representatives at such meetings.
ollama_generated: (i)    The expenses accrued under the terms of the TAT-14 MOU, as outlined in the TAT-14 budget, shall be borne; (ii)  The Supplier is responsible for costs due under the Supply Contract, except where such costs are explicitly excluded or unreasonable in amount; (iii)  Other expenses incurred under the supervision of the Managing Group, Procurement Group, or any authorized Party shall be shared among the parties, with each party only bearing its fair share. These costs include, but are not limited to, engineering, design, materials, manufacturing, procurement and inspection, installation, removal (with appropriate salvage), cable ship and other ship costs, route surveys, burial, testing associated with laying or installation, customs duties, taxes (excluding income tax imposed upon the net income of a Party), appropriate financial charges, supervision, billing activities, overheads, insurance premiums (unless a party elects to self-insure, in which case a reasonable allowance will suffice), and any other costs reasonably incurred for the purpose of, or properly chargeable, in respect of such engineering, provision, construction, installation, and laying of Segment S of TAT-14. Such costs shall exclude expenses related to the attendance by Parties' representatives at meetings, including Data Gathering and General Committee meetings, as well as meetings of the Managing Group, Procurement Group, and its Working Groups. The preparation and attendance by Parties' representatives at such meetings will be borne individually by each party. September 2, 1998                                                        Page 16

original: 14.2     The CBP will receive  invoices  from the Supplier for the costs due and included in the Supply  Contract.  The Parties  shall  promptly  render invoices to the CBP for the cost of items directly  incurred by them in accordance with Subparagraph  13.1. The CBP shall promptly render bills to each of the Parties for such Party's pro rata share of costs due and included in the invoices it has received in accordance with Schedule B.
ollama_generated:
14.2 Each Party will submit invoices to the CBP for the costs they have directly incurred, as specified in Subparagraph 13.1. The CBP will receive such invoices from the Supplier for the costs due and included in the Supply Contract, and promptly process them. Upon receipt of these processed invoices by each Party, the CBP will issue corresponding bills to each Party, detailing their proportionate share of the total costs detailed in the invoices, as outlined in Schedule B.

In this revised clause, the sequence of events is changed slightly, with the Parties submitting their invoices first and the CBP processing them before issuing bills. This change may be perceived as a slight shift in responsibility from the CBP to the Parties for initiating the billing process.

original: - -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- September 2, 1998                                                        Page 18 14.8     As soon as practicable  after the RFPA Date, the amount of each Party's share of the costs of Segment S shall be computed by the CBP which will make appropriate  adjustments and render any necessary bills or arrange for any necessary refunds by way of final settlement in order that each Party  may  bear its  appropriate  share of the  costs as  provided  in Subparagraph 14.1.
ollama_generated: 14.8     At a time reasonably convenient to each Party, following the RFPA Date, the computation of each Party's proportionate share of the costs associated with Segment S shall be initiated by either Party. The initiating Party shall then seek confirmation from the other Party, after which the Computation Party will calculate, adjust as necessary, and communicate the results to both Parties. Any bills or refunds required for final settlement, due to inaccuracies or discrepancies, will be facilitated by the Computation Party. Each Party is responsible for promptly reviewing the calculation results and accepting or challenging them within a reasonable timeframe, as set out in Subparagraph 14.1. In the event of any dispute, the matter shall be resolved through negotiation between the Parties, with binding arbitration to follow if necessary.

original: 15.3     Each  Terminal  Party  shall  provide,  within the Country of its Cable Station,  connection to TAT-14 at the SDH Interface  Equipment  levels, VC12,  VC3 or VC4  levels,  to  Parties  and  Purchasers  on terms  and conditions  to be agreed by the  Terminal  Party and the other Party or Purchaser under a separate agreement.
ollama_generated: 15.3   Each Terminal Party shall receive, within their respective Countries of Cable Station, access to TAT-14 at SDH Interface Equipment levels, VC12, VC3, or VC4, from the other Parties or Purchasers, subject to the terms and conditions mutually agreed upon in a separate agreement between the providing Party and the recipient. The obligation for providing such access shall be assumed by the Party offering the service.

original: Parties,  upon request,  suitable space and connection  with TAT-14 for operating and technical control purposes relating to capacity assigned, or to be assigned,  to them in TAT-14.  AT&T and SPRINT  shall  provide such space in a building  separate,  but adjacent to its cable  station and located on the land which forms a part of Segments T1 and T2. These U.S.  Parties  shall have the right to provide  their own personnel and equipment in such space.  Such U.S.  Parties shall  reimburse  AT&T and SPRINT  for the  reasonable  costs  incurred  by  AT&T  and  SPRINT  in providing  such space and  connection  pursuant to this  Paragraph  15, including but not limited to, the costs of any additional building that may be reasonably required 15.7     The Managing Group is responsible  for  determining and setting service level objectives for access and activation  intervals  jointly with the Terminal Parties.
modified:
Parties shall not be obligated to request suitable space and connection with TAT-14 for operating and technical control purposes, unless they have a need or requirement to do so in relation to the capacity assigned, or about to be assigned, to them in TAT-14. AT&T and SPRINT shall not be required to provide such space within a building separate but adjacent to its cable station, although they may choose to do so at their own discretion. The provision of this space and connection by AT&T and SPRINT will not be mandatory, and these parties reserve the right to charge for any costs incurred in providing it, including the construction of any additional building that may be deemed necessary.

As for service level objectives for access and activation intervals, the Terminal Parties shall have the primary responsibility for jointly determining and setting these objectives with the Managing Group. The Managing Group's role will be to advise and consult, rather than dictate, in this matter.

original: 16       OPERATION AND MAINTENANCE OF SEGMENTS T AND S 16.1     The  Terminal  Parties,  on behalf of the Parties and  Purchasers,  are responsible for operation and maintenance as follows:
modified:
16.1 **Upkeep and Maintenance Responsibilities Regarding Segments T and S**

The Parties and Purchasers, respectively represented by the Terminal Parties, are entrusted with the task of overseeing and maintaining these segments in accordance with the following guidelines:

This revised clause shifts the responsibility of operation and maintenance of Segments T and S from the Terminal Parties to the Parties and Purchasers. However, it is essential to note that the Terminal Parties act as their representatives in this matter. This change can be seen as a delegation or assignment of duties rather than an outright transfer of responsibility.

original: 16.4     Sixty (60) days before the RFPA Date the Maintenance  Authorities shall submit for review by the Procurement Group and approval by the Managing Group appropriate  practices and procedures for the continued operation and  maintenance of Segment S. The Maintenance  Authorities  shall each provide  information to the  Procurement  Group regarding the practices and  procedures  for the continued  operation and  maintenance of their respective  Segments.  The  Maintenance  Authorities  shall  also  each develop  and  furnish  such  budgetary  estimates  of the  cost of such operation  and   maintenance  of  TAT-14  as  the  Managing  Group  may reasonably   request  and   provide   this   information   to  the  F&A Subcommittee.  Following  the RFPA Date,  the  Maintenance  Authorities shall each  provide  the  Managing  Group  with such  reports as it may reasonably require on the operation and maintenance of TAT-14 including any proposals for planned  repair or  improvement  work,  together with appropriately revised budgetary estimates relating to the operation and maintenance  of  TAT-14  and  the  inclusion  of  TAT-14  in any  cable maintenance agreements.  The Procurement Group may review and amend the practices and procedures  for the operation and  maintenance of Segment S, subject to the approval of the Managing  Group.  The Managing  Group may revise the  allocation  of  responsibility  for the  operation  and maintenance of Segment S.
ollama_generated:
16.4: Ninety (90) days preceding the RFPA Date, the Maintenance Authorities are obligated to submit proposed practices and procedures for the continued operation and maintenance of Segment S to both the Procurement Group and the Managing Group for review and approval. Each Maintenance Authority shall disclose the methods they deem necessary for the operation and maintenance of their respective Segments to the Procurement Group. Additionally, each Maintenance Authority is expected to prepare and present budgetary estimates for the operation and maintenance of TAT-14, as reasonably requested by the Managing Group, and share these with the F&A Subcommittee. Following the RFPA Date, each Maintenance Authority must furnish the Managing Group with any reports required on the operation and maintenance of TAT-14, including proposals for planned repairs or enhancements, accompanied by revised budgetary estimates for the operation and maintenance of TAT-14 and potential integration of TAT-14 into any cable maintenance agreements. The Procurement Group retains the right to modify the proposed practices and procedures for the operation and maintenance of Segment S, subject to the Managing Group's approval. The Managing Group reserves the option to reassess the distribution of responsibilities for the operation and maintenance of Segment S.

In this revised clause:
- Timeframe for submission is extended from 60 to 90 days before RFPA Date
- Maintenance Authorities are obligated to submit proposed practices rather than having an obligation to provide "appropriate" practices (potentially allowing for less stringent or non-optimal solutions)
- The Procurement Group may review and amend the practices, but the approval of the Managing Group is still required
- The Managing Group retains the discretion to reassess the distribution of responsibilities, implying that there might be a possibility for redistribution of responsibilities after RFPA Date.

original: 16.5     The   Maintenance   Authorities,   individually   or   collectively  as appropriate,  shall each use all  reasonable  efforts to  maintain,  or cause to be  maintained,  economically  the  Segments for which each is responsible,  in efficient  working order.  Each Maintenance  Authority shall  discharge  its   responsibility  in  a  manner  consistent  with applicable international submarine cable maintenance practices and with an objective of achieving effective and timely repairs when necessary.
ollama_generated: 16.5 The Maintenance Authorities, singularly or jointly as the situation requires, shall endeavor to make a good-faith effort, rather than utilizing all reasonable efforts, in maintaining or arranging for the maintenance of their respective Segments, aiming for operational efficiency. It is understood that each Maintenance Authority shall fulfill its duties with due regard for applicable international submarine cable maintenance practices and with the goal of prioritizing preventive measures to minimize the need for repairs, rather than exclusively focusing on immediate and timely repairs when required. This approach aims to strike a balance between effectiveness and efficiency in the performance of maintenance tasks.

original: 16.6     The  Maintenance  Authorities  shall  have  the  right  to  temporarily de-activate  Segment S, or any part thereof,  in order to perform their duties  as  Maintenance  Authorities.   Prior  to  such  de-activation, reasonable notice shall be given to and coordination shall be made with the other  Parties.  To the extent  possible,  sixty (60) days prior to initiating  action,  the  Maintenance  Authority(ies)  shall advise the other Parties in writing of the timing, scope, and costs of significant planned  maintenance  operations,  of  significant  changes to existing operation and maintenance methods, and of contractual  arrangements for cable ships that will or may have a significant  impact on operation or maintenance costs. Should one or more Parties representing at least 5 % of the total  voting  interests  specified in Schedule B wish to review such an  operation  or change  prior to its  occurrence,  such Party or Parties  shall  notify the  Maintenance  Authorities  involved  and the Managing  Group  chairperson in writing within thirty (30) days of such advice.  Upon such  notification,  the  Managing  Group shall  initiate action to convene an ad hoc meeting for such review.
ollama_generated: 16.6 The Maintenance Parties retain the discretionary power to temporarily suspend Segment S, or any part thereof, in accordance with their maintenance responsibilities. Adequate notice and coordination should be provided to all other Parties prior to such suspension, however, timing may be adjusted based on unforeseen circumstances or urgent maintenance requirements. The Maintenance Party(ies) will strive to inform the other Parties at least sixty (60) days in advance about substantial planned maintenance activities, changes to established operational and maintenance methods, and agreements concerning cable ships that might significantly affect operation or maintenance expenses. In case no party holding a collective 5% or more of the voting interests as outlined in Schedule B requests a review of such an operation or change within thirty (30) days of receiving such notification, the Maintenance Parties may proceed without further consultation. Should a request for review be made, the Managing Group shall convene an ad hoc meeting to discuss the matter at the earliest convenience.

original: 16.11    Each Maintenance  Authority shall be authorized to pursue claims in its own name, on behalf of the Parties,  in the event of any damage or loss to TAT-14 and may file  appropriate  lawsuits or other  proceedings  on behalf of the Parties.  Subject to obtaining the prior  concurrence  of the Managing  Group,  a Maintenance  Authority may settle or compromise any claims and execute releases and settlement  agreements on behalf of the Parties as  necessary  to effect a settlement  or  compromise.  Any money  ordered by the  tribunal or under a  settlement  approved by the Managing  Group shall be shared  among all Parties in  accordance  with Schedule B.
ollama_generated:
16.11  Each Maintenance Authority retains the right, but not the obligation, to initiate claims in its own name, acting as an agent for the Parties, in instances of damage or loss to TAT-14. However, such actions must receive prior approval from the Managing Group before any lawsuits or proceedings can be filed on behalf of the Parties.

If a Maintenance Authority chooses to pursue settlement or compromise of any claims, it may do so after obtaining the necessary concurrence from the Managing Group. Settlement agreements and releases executed shall be binding only for the specific claim in question, not extending to any other claims or disputes between the Parties.

Any monetary compensation awarded by a tribunal or agreed upon in a settlement approved by the Managing Group will be distributed among all Parties according to the proportions outlined in Schedule B. The Maintenance Authorities shall bear their own costs associated with pursuing, settling, or compromising claims, unless otherwise specified in this Agreement or agreed upon by all Parties.

original: - -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- September 2, 1998                                                        Page 22 17       OPERATION AND MAINTENANCE COSTS OF SEGMENT S - ALLOCATION AND BILLING 17.1     The  operation and  maintenance  costs for Segment S shall be shared by the Parties in the  relevant  proportions  specified in Schedule B. The Managing  Group shall be  responsible  for  determining  the method and procedure  for  the  charging  of  O&M  costs  to  Purchasers  and  the distribution  of any credit to the Parties in accordance  with Schedule 17.2     The operation and maintenance  costs to which  Subparagraph 17.1 refers are the costs  reasonably  incurred in operating  and  maintaining  the facilities  involved,  including,  but  not  limited  to,  the  cost of attendance,  testing,  adjustments,  repairs (including repairs at sea) and replacements,  cable ships (including standby costs), re-burial and the replacement of plant, cable depots,  maintenance and repair devices that are or may  hereafter  become  available,  customs  duties,  taxes (except  income tax imposed upon the income of a Party) paid in respect of such facilities,  billing activities,  appropriate financial charges attributable   to  other  Parties'   shares  of  costs  incurred  by  a Maintenance Authority at the rate at which the appropriate  Maintenance Authority  generally  incurred  such  financial  charges,  supervision, overheads  and costs and  expenses  reasonably  incurred  on account of claims made by or against other  persons in respect of such  facilities or any part thereof and damages or compensation  payable by the Parties concerned  on account of such claims and costs for the  Managing  Group and the NA costs, General Committee meeting costs, expenses and damages or compensation  payable to the Parties on account of such claims shall be shared by them in the same  proportions  as they share the operation and  maintenance  costs of the  relevant  Segment S under  Subparagraph 17.3     The Managing  Group may  authorize  the  provision of special tools and test  equipment for use on board cable ships which are required for the maintenance  and repair of TAT-14.  The related costs may include,  but not be limited to, the costs, or an appropriate share thereof,  for the provision, storage and maintenance of this equipment.
ollama_generated:
September 2, 1998

Page 22, Item 17: OPERATION AND MAINTENANCE COSTS OF SEGMENT S - ALLOCATION AND BILLING

17.1 The Parties shall bear the operation and maintenance costs of Segment S proportionately as specified in Schedule B. The Managing Group retains discretion over the method and procedure for allocating O&M costs to Purchasers, with any credits or surpluses distributed among the Parties according to Schedule 17.2

17.2 The operation and maintenance costs referred to in Subparagraph 17.1 encompass expenses reasonably incurred in managing and maintaining the involved facilities, including but not limited to: attendance, testing, adjustments, repairs (including offshore repairs), replacements, cable ships (including standby fees), re-burial, plant and depot replacement, maintenance and repair equipment, customs duties, taxes (excluding income tax), associated financial charges, supervision, overheads, and expenses related to claims made by or against other parties in respect of these facilities. Any additional costs or damages incurred by the Parties due to such claims shall also be shared among them according to their proportional share as set out in Subparagraph 17.3

17.3 The Managing Group has the authority to approve the use of specialized tools and test equipment on board cable ships for the maintenance and repair of TAT-14. Associated costs, or an equitable portion thereof, may include provision, storage, and maintenance expenses of this equipment. In the event that such equipment is utilized, the related costs will be distributed among the Parties in the same proportion as their operation and maintenance cost obligations for Segment S under Subparagraph 17.1.

original: 17.4     The Maintenance Authorities  individually,  the Terminal Parties or the CBP, as  appropriate,  shall bill the Parties in  accordance  with this Paragraph 17. Bills shall not be rendered more  frequently  than once a quarter and shall be paid by the end of the month  following  the month in which the bills were rendered.  The billing procedures  specified in Subparagraphs  14.3,  14.4,  14.5,  and 14.9 shall be applicable to all bills rendered pursuant to this Paragraph 17.
ollama_generated: 17.4 The Parties, individually or jointly as deemed appropriate by the Maintenance Authorities, Terminal Parties, or CBP, are collectively responsible for receiving and settling bills in accordance with this Paragraph 17. Bills shall be rendered at least once every three months, with the expectation that they will be settled within the initial month following the month during which they were issued. The billing procedures detailed in Subparagraphs 14.3, 14.4, 14.5, and 14.9 are obligatorily applicable to all bills generated in accordance with this Paragraph 17, implying that the Parties may have to adjust their payment schedules accordingly.

original: 18.2     For the use of Segments T1 to T7, the  respective  Terminal Party shall identify  the charge to cover  capital  costs and cost of  maintenance, supervision and operation of that Segment.
ollama_generated: 18.2 In regard to the utilization of Segments T1 to T7, it is incumbent upon each Terminal Party to determine and communicatedy clarify the fee structure encompassing capital expenses and ongoing costs related to maintenance, oversight, and operation for those specific Segments. This responsibility extends to any changes in these charges over the term of this agreement.

original: 18.9     If any of the Cable  Stations  are not  available  for the  landing and termination of TAT-14 for any reason,  the relevant  Terminal Party, in agreement with the other Parties,  shall take all necessary measures to ensure that another suitable Cable Station will be available for TAT-14 on fair and equitable terms for the duration of this Agreement.
ollama_generated: 18.9 In the event that a suitable Cable Station is unavailable for the landing and termination of TAT-14 under the terms of this Agreement, it shall be the collective responsibility of all Parties to negotiate and agree upon an alternative Cable Station, if feasible and on mutually acceptable terms, with the understanding that any delay or additional costs incurred as a result shall not constitute a breach of this Agreement by any Party.

original: 18.10    Nothing  contained  in this  Agreement  shall be  deemed to vest in any Party, other than the owner of the relevant Segment, any salvage rights in Segments T1 to T7 or in the respective Cable Station or in any Cable Station substituted for any of them.
ollama_generated: 18.10: It is explicitly stated within this Agreement that no Party shall be considered as acquiring any salvage rights, beyond those belonging to the owners of Segments T1 to T7, for the respective Cable Station or any subsequent Cable Station serving as a replacement for any of them. The implication being that all such rights remain exclusively with their rightful owners.

original: (i)    On the RFPA Date, or as soon after as  practicable  but no later than one (1) year after RFPA,  the Terminal  Parties will submit invoices to the CBP for their capital cost of the Cable Stations Right of Use. In the event a Terminal  Party  incurs  additional capital  costs  related  to TAT-14  after the RFPA  Date,  these invoices  shall  also  be  submitted  to  the  CBP  as  soon  as practicable; (ii)   by the 1st of April of each  year,  the  Terminal  Parties  will submit  invoices to the CBP for their O&M charges  incurred  for the Cable Stations Right of Use for the previous calendar year; (iii)  the  Parties  shall be  billed  individually  by the CBP for the Cable  Station  Right of Use  operation  and  maintenance  costs shared in the proportions specified in Schedule 13; (iv)   the billed  Party shall pay such bills to the CBP, by the end of the month  following the month in which the bills were rendered.
ollama_generated:
1. By the RFPA Date, or as soon thereafter as possible but no later than one (1) year from the RFPA Date, each Terminal Party shall submit invoices to the CBP for their capital costs associated with the Cable Stations Right of Use. If a Terminal Party incurs additional capital costs related to TAT-14 after the RFPA Date, these invoices should be submitted as soon as practically feasible but, in any event, within two (2) years from such incurred costs.

2. By the 1st of April each year, the Terminal Parties shall submit their O&M charges invoices for the Cable Stations Right of Use for the preceding calendar year to the CBP.

3. The CBP will bill each Party individually for their proportionate share of the Cable Station Right of Use operation and maintenance costs, as specified in Schedule 13.

4. The receiving Party shall pay any bills received from the CBP for the Cable Station Right of Use operation and maintenance costs within thirty (30) days after the billing date. In case of non-payment by the due date, a late fee may be imposed at the discretion of the CBP.

original: 19.2     The Procurement  Group shall ensure that the Supply  Contract  requires the Supplier to obtain from its  contractors  and  subcontractors  such supporting  records  as are  specified  in  Subparagraph  19.1  of this Agreement  and to maintain  such records for a period of five (5) years from the RFPA Date.
ollama_generated: 19.2a In accordance with this Agreement, the Supplier is responsible for procuring and preserving, for a duration of five (5) years following the RFPA Date, any supporting records as outlined in Subparagraph 19.1, from their contractors and subcontractors, as per the terms of the Supply Contract.

original: 19.7     Any Party keeping and maintaining books, records, vouchers and accounts of  costs  pursuant  to  Subparagraphs  19.4,  19.5  and  19.6  of this Agreement  shall  afford the  Parties  the right to review at their own expense  said  books,  records,  vouchers  and  accounts  of  costs  in accordance   with  the  audit   procedures   established   by  the  F&A Subcommittee.
ollama_generated: 19.7: Granting reciprocity, each Party is entitled to inspect, at their discretion and expense, the books, records, vouchers, and accounts of costs pertaining to Subparagraphs 19.4, 19.5, and 19.6, subject to the audit procedures set forth by the F&A Subcommittee; provided that this right to inspect shall not be construed as an obligation for any Party to proactively provide such access or documentation.

original: - -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- September 2, 1998                                                        Page 27 23       FORCE MAJEURE If any Party cannot fulfill its obligations in this Agreement due to an event  beyond its  reasonable  control,  including,  but not limited to flood,  exceptionally  severe  weather,  hurricane,   explosion,  civil disorder,  war or military  operations,  national  or local  emergency, action or inaction of government or other competent authority, it shall not be liable to the other  Parties  for such  delay in  performing  or failure to perform and shall give  notice to the other  Parties as soon as reasonably practicable after the event has occurred.
ollama_generated:
- -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- September 2, 1998                                                         Page 27 23       EXCEPTIONAL EVENTS AFFECTING PERFORMANCE

Should any Party find it excessively challenging to meet its obligations under this Agreement due to an extraordinary event not foreseeable or preventable by reasonable means, such as but not limited to flood, unusually harsh weather, hurricane, explosion, civil unrest, war or military activities, national or local emergency, regulatory changes, or ineffective actions of governmental entities or other competent authorities; it shall be released from liability towards the other Parties for any resulting delay in performance or failure to meet these obligations. Notification of such an event should be provided to the other Parties as expeditiously as feasible once the event has transpired.

original: 24.2     If any Party is obliged by a final judgment of a competent  tribunal or under a settlement  approved by the Managing  Group,  to discharge  any claim,   including  all  reasonable   costs  and  expenses   associated therewith,  resulting from the  implementation  of this Agreement,  the Party which has  discharged the claim shall be entitled to receive from the  other  Parties  reimbursement  in the  proportions  as set  out in Schedule B.
ollama_generated: 24.2. In the event that any Party incurs expenses or suffers a financial loss due to a claim arising from the execution of this Agreement, and such claim is either upheld by a final court ruling or settled with the approval of the Managing Group, the Party incurring the expense shall be entitled to seek reimbursement from the other Parties in the proportions specified in Schedule B. This clause places the onus on the affected Party to pursue reimbursement, rather than implying an automatic entitlement.

original: 24.5     In the  case  where a claim  is  brought  against  one of the  Terminal Parties,  in its  capacity  as a  Maintenance  Authority  for TAT-14 in respect of a  sacrificed  anchor  and/or  loss of, or damage to fishing gear,  then such  Terminal  Party may settle such a claim for an amount not greater than $ 25,000 on each  occasion or such an amount as agreed by the Managing Group from time to time, and obtain reimbursement under Subparagraph 24.2.
ollama_generated: 24.5     If a claim is instituted against any of the Terminal Parties in their role as Maintenance Authorities for TAT-14 regarding a lost or damaged anchor, fishing gear, or related equipment, it shall be the responsibility of the affected party to first seek reimbursement under Subparagraph 24.2, following which such Terminal Party may negotiate and pay up to $25,000 on each occasion, or any amount agreed upon by the Managing Group at the time, as a settlement for the claim. The settling Terminal Party shall thereafter have the right to seek reimbursement from the other Terminal Parties for the amount paid.

original: 29       CONFIDENTIALITY 29.1     All data and  information  that is acquired or received by any Party in anticipation of or under this Agreement shall be confidential and shall not be divulged in any - -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- September 2, 1998                                                        Page 30 way to any third party, without the prior written approval of the other Parties,  nor shall it be used for any purpose beyond the scope of this Agreement. Any Party may, without such approval, disclose such data and information to:
ollama_generated:
29. SHARED CONFIDENTIALITY

29.1 In the course of our collaboration under this Agreement, each Party may acquire or receive sensitive data and information. This data shall be treated with discretion and not disseminated indiscriminately. Any Party reserves the right to share such confidential information with third parties, provided it is in writing that this disclosure is necessary for the execution of our obligations under this Agreement. Each Party acknowledges that any unauthorized disclosure or utilization of this data outside the parameters of this Agreement may constitute a breach.

original: (i)    the employees of that Party; or (ii)   the extent  required by any applicable  laws, or the requirement of any recognized  stock  exchange in compliance  with its rules and  regulations  or in the  case if a party  wholly  owned by a sovereign  government,  by the rules of governance of the Party, (iii)  any   government   agency  or  regulatory   authority   lawfully requesting such information or to which such  information  needs to be  submitted  in order to obtain  any  necessary  consent or approval', or (iv)   any Court of competent  jurisdiction  acting in pursuance of its powers; or (v)    professional  advisors,  auditors  and  bankers or any bona fide intending  assignee  upon  obtaining  a similar  undertaking  of confidentiality; or (vi)   the  extent  that  such data  and/or  information  is  generally available to the public.
ollama_generated: (i)    the employees of the mentioned Party; or (ii)   as mandated by any relevant laws, or the stipulations of a recognized stock exchange in adherence with its guidelines, or if a party is entirely owned by a sovereign government, by the prescribed rules and regulations of the said Party; or (iii)  any government agency, regulatory authority, or third party with a legitimate demand for such information, or to whom such information must be submitted for obtaining necessary consent or approval; or (iv)   any Court of competent jurisdiction exercising its powers; or (v)    professional advisors, auditors, bankers, or any potential assignee upon taking an oath of confidentiality, with the exception of; (vi)  the extent that such data and/or information is publicly accessible and disclosed.

original: 30.2     A Party may assign the whole of its rights  under this  Agreement  to a successor  by  law,  Subsidiary  or  Affiliate  of  such  Party,  or  a corporation or an entity  jointly  controlling or under the same common control as such Party,  provided that the assigning  Party shall remain jointly and severally  liable with the assignee for the  performance of this  Agreement for the duration of the  Agreement.  The Managing Group may  decide  that the  assigning  Party  will not  remain  jointly  and severally  liable  with  the  assignee  for  the  performance  of  this Agreement for the duration of the Agreement provided that the assigning Party will give  notice to the other  Parties in a timely  manner,  and provided  that  the  assignee  agrees  in  writing  to be  bound by the provisions of this Agreement.
ollama_generated: 30.2. Either Party retains the discretion to delegate its obligations under this Agreement to a successor-in-law, Subsidiary, or Affiliate of such Party, or to a corporation or entity jointly controlling or under the same common control as such Party. However, the delegating Party shall not be released from its liability for any breach of this Agreement during the term hereof; rather, it will remain solely liable until such time that the assignee assumes full responsibility and compliance with this Agreement, upon written agreement by both parties. The Managing Group reserves the right to approve the delegating Party's release from joint and several liability, subject to the approval of the assignee and prompt notification to all other Parties involved in this Agreement.

original: - -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- September 2, 1998                                                        Page 3l 30.4     If a governmental or other regulatory  approval is required lawfully to effect  the  proposed   assignment,   the  assigning   Party  shall  be responsible,  at its  own  expense,  for  preparing  and  pursuing  the application  for such  approval.  Such  approval  shall be  obtained in advance  of  the  assignment   unless  the  relevant   governmental  or regulatory  authority  has  formally  indicated  in  writing  that  the transfer may proceed in advance of the receipt of the formal approval.
ollama_generated: 30.4. In the event that a legal and necessary governmental or regulatory approval is mandatory for the execution of the proposed assignment, it shall be the responsibility of the assigning Party to bear the costs associated with preparing and submitting the application for such approval. However, should the relevant authority provide written confirmation that the transfer can proceed without prior formal approval, the assignment may take place subject to the receipt of such confirmation, yet the onus remains on the assigning Party to ensure compliance with any subsequent requirements or approvals that may be necessary.

original: 33       PARAGRAPH HEADINGS, REFERENCES Headings  are inserted  for  convenience  only and shall not affect the interpretation of this Agreement,  References to recitals, clauses, and attachments  are to  recitals  and  clauses  of and  Schedules  to this Agreement.  Unless the context otherwise requires,  words importing the singular  number  shall  include the plural and vice versa.  Unless the context  otherwise   requires,   references  to  a  person  include  an individual,  firm, body, corporation,  unincorporated association,  and government or  governmental,  semi-governmental  or local  authority or agency. Reference to the male shall include the female.
ollama_generated:
33. HEADINGS AND REFERENCES

Headings are included for ease of reference only and should not be construed as altering the meaning of this Agreement. References to recitals, sections, and appendices will refer to the corresponding parts of this Agreement. For clarity, when the context does not dictate otherwise, terms in the singular shall encompass the plural, and vice versa. Moreover, references to a person encompass an individual, firm, organization, corporation, unincorporated association, government entity (federal, state, or local), semi-governmental agency, or any other administrative body, regardless of gender.

original: 35.3     For revision to the relevant  Schedules,  in accordance with Paragraphs 9, 11 and 21 of this Agreement, the agreement in writing of the Parties having  their  ownership   percentages   increased  or  their  capacity assignment changed will be required to formalize the revised Schedules, which will be considered as part of this Agreement, in substitution for the preceding version of those Schedules.
modified: 35.3 Amendments to the relevant Schedules, as stipulated in Paragraphs 9, 11, and 21 of this Agreement, shall only become effective upon the mutual written agreement of the Parties, regardless of any changes in their ownership percentages or capacity assignments. In such cases, the new versions of those Schedules will supersede and replace the previous ones, but will not be considered as amendments to this Agreement itself. Instead, they will constitute separate annexes appended to this Agreement.

original: 36       INTERPRETATION OF THE AGREEMENT AND SETTLEMENT OF DISPUTES 36.1     The  construction,  interpretation  and  performance  of this Agreement shall be governed by the laws of Switzerland,  except for its conflicts of law principles.
ollama_generated:
36. INTERPRETATION OF THE AGREEMENT AND RESOLUTION OF DISPUTES

36.1 In matters concerning the construction, interpretation, and performance of this Agreement, a different perspective prevails: The applicable legal framework shall be determined by the laws of Switzerland, yet excluding its conflict-of-laws provisions that might otherwise direct us to another jurisdiction.

original: The  arbitration  shall  take  place in  Geneva,  Switzerland,  and the proceedings shall be conducted in the English language. The award shall be final and binding and the Parties hereby waive all means of recourse to the courts of - -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- September 2, 1998                                                        Page 33 Switzerland or any other Country.  Jucgment on the award may be entered in any court of competent Jurisdiction.
ollama_generated:
The resolution of disputes arising from this agreement shall occur through arbitration, which shall be held in a location chosen at the discretion of either Party, with the proviso that it must be a mutually acceptable and neutral venue. The proceedings will be conducted in the English language.

The award rendered by the arbitrator(s) shall be binding and final, subject to review for errors of law or procedural irregularities at the discretion of either Party. This clause does not preclude either Party from seeking interim measures or emergency relief from any court of competent jurisdiction during the arbitration process.

Each Party hereby acknowledges and consents to the jurisdiction of any court of competent jurisdiction for the purpose of enforcing the arbitral award. However, this does not constitute a waiver of the right to challenge the enforcement of the award in accordance with applicable laws and regulations.
